cards.name: Homarid Spawning Bed
cards.text: {1}{U}{U}, Sacrifice a blue creature: Create X 1/1 blue Camarid creature tokens, where X is the sacrificed creature's converted mana cost.
cards.originalText: {1}{U}{U}: Sacrifice a blue creature to put X Camarid tokens into play, where X is the casting cost of the sacrificed creature. Treat these tokens as 1/1 blue creatures.

cards.name: Homarid Warrior
cards.text: {U}: Homarid Warrior gains shroud until end of turn and doesn't untap during your next untap step. Tap Homarid Warrior. (A creature with shroud can't be the target of spells or abilities.)

rulings.text: It taps when the ability resolves if it was not already tapped. It may be used even if it is already tapped.
Does not cause Auras on it to be removed when the effect is activated. An Aura on the battlefield is neither a spell nor an ability.

cards.originalText: {U}: Homarid Warrior may not be the target of spells or effects until end of turn and does not untap as normal during your next untap phase. If Homarid Warrior is untapped, tap it.

cards.name: Merseine
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Merseine enters the battlefield with three net counters on it.
Enchanted creature doesn't untap during its controller's untap step if Merseine has a net counter on it.
Pay enchanted creature's mana cost: Remove a net counter from Merseine. Only the controller of the enchanted creature may activate this ability.

rulings.text: Can remove as many counters per turn as you want to and this can be done at any time instants are legal.
The cost that needs to be paid includes colored mana requirements.

cards.originalText: Put three net counters on Merseine when it is brought into play. Target creature Merseine enchants does not untap as normal during its controller's untap phase as long as any net counters remain. As a fast effect, target creature's controller may pay creature's casting cost to remove a net counter.

cards.name: River Merfolk
cards.text: {U}: River Merfolk gains mountainwalk until end of turn. (It can't be blocked as long as defending player controls a Mountain.)
cards.flavor:
"Dwelling in icy mountain streams near Goblin and Orcish foes, the River Merfolk were known for their stoicism."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. V
cards.originalText: {U}: Mountainwalk until end of turn

cards.name: Seasinger
cards.text:
When you control no Islands, sacrifice Seasinger.
You may choose not to untap Seasinger during your untap step.
{T}: Gain control of target creature whose controller controls an Island for as long as you control Seasinger and Seasinger remains tapped.

rulings.text: You do not lose control of the stolen creature if it stops being a creature. You only lose control if Seasinger leaves your control or becomes untapped.

If a creature's controller doesn't control an Island, that creature is an illegal target. Whether that player controls an Island is checked both when Seasinger's ability is activated and when it resolves. However, targeting restrictions aren't checked continually while a spell or ability is on the stack.

Whether you control Seasinger is checked continually, starting when the ability is activated. If, before the ability resolves, there's any point at which you don't control Seasinger, the ability has no effect — even if you control Seasinger again by the time the ability resolves. The same is true regarding whether Seasinger remains tapped.

cards.originalText:
Bury Seasinger if you control no islands.
{T}: Gain control of a target creature if its controller controls at least one island. You lose control of target creature if Seasinger leaves play, if you lose control of Seasinger, or if Seasinger becomes untapped. You may choose not to untap Seasinger as normal during your untap phase.

cards.name: Svyelunite Priest
cards.text: {U}{U}, {T}: Target creature gains shroud until end of turn. Activate this ability only during your upkeep. (It can't be the target of spells or abilities.)
cards.flavor:
"Early Vodalians worshipped Svyelun, goddess of the Pearl Moon. Later she became a more abstract figure."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. V

rulings.text: Does not cause Auras on the creature to be removed when the ability is activated. An Aura on the battlefield is neither a spell nor an ability.
The effect prevents spells or the effects of permanents from targeting the creature. Auras which confer an ability (such as Lance or Firebreathing) are not prevented.

cards.originalText: {U}{U}, {T}: Target creature may not be the target of spells or effects until end of turn. Use this ability only during your upkeep.

cards.name: Tidal Flats
cards.text: {U}{U}: For each attacking creature without flying, its controller may pay {1}. If that player doesn't, creatures you control blocking that creature gain first strike until end of turn.

rulings.text: Can be used more than once in a turn. Each time, the opponent can pay to prevent giving first strike to a creature, but this payment only stops the current activation and not future activations of Tidal Flats.
The payment is made when the Tidal Flats effect resolves.
First Strike is granted to your creatures currently blocking non-Flyers when this effect resolves.

cards.originalText: {U}{U}: All your creatures that are blocking any non-flying creatures gain first strike until end of turn. The attacking player may pay {1} for each attacking creature to prevent Tidal Flats from giving that creature's blockers first strike.

cards.name: Tidal Influence
cards.text:
Cast this spell only if no permanents named Tidal Influence are on the battlefield.
Tidal Influence enters the battlefield with a tide counter on it.
At the beginning of your upkeep, put a tide counter on Tidal Influence.
As long as there is exactly one tide counter on Tidal Influence, all blue creatures get -2/-0.
As long as there are exactly three tide counters on Tidal Influence, all blue creatures get +2/+0.
Whenever there are four or more tide counters on Tidal Influence, remove all tide counters from it.

rulings.text: As soon as the number of counters on this card changes, so does the power of blue creatures.

cards.originalText:
Put a tide counter on Tidal Influence when it is brought into play and during your upkeep. If there is one tide counter on Tidal Influence, all blue creatures get -2/-0. If there are three tide counters on Tidal Influence, all blue creatures get +2/+0. When there are four tide counters on Tidal Influence, remove them all.
You may not cast Tidal Influence if there is another Tidal Influence in play.

cards.name: Vodalian Knights
cards.text:
First strike
Vodalian Knights can't attack unless defending player controls an Island.
When you control no Islands, sacrifice Vodalian Knights.
{U}: Vodalian Knights gains flying until end of turn.
cards.flavor: Fear the Knight leaping from the water into the air, weapon ready.
cards.originalText:
First strike
{U}: Flying until end of turn
Vodalian Knights may not attack unless opponent controls at least one island. Bury Vodalian Knights if you control no islands.

cards.name: Vodalian Mage
cards.text: {U}, {T}: Counter target spell unless its controller pays {1}.
cards.flavor:
"Vodalian Mages are remarkable. Their merchants bring them arcane lore and devices from across the seas."
—Lydia Wynforth, Mayor of Trokair
cards.originalText: {U}, {T}: Counters a target spell if caster of target spell does not pay an additional {1}. Play this ability as an interrupt.

cards.name: Vodalian Mage
cards.text: {U}, {T}: Counter target spell unless its controller pays {1}.
cards.flavor: Vodalian Mages were invaluable in magical combat. Unfortunately, the Homarids raided with strength, numbers, and very little magic.
cards.originalText: {U}, {T}: Counters a target spell if caster of target spell does not pay an additional {1}. Play this ability as an interrupt.

cards.name: Vodalian Mage
cards.text: {U}, {T}: Counter target spell unless its controller pays {1}.
cards.flavor:
"Come back, cowards! Everyone knows Merfolk can't wield magic!"
—Pashadar Dirf, Goblin Flotilla Commander, last words
cards.originalText: {U}, {T}: Counters a target spell if caster of target spell does not pay an additional {1}. Play this ability as an interrupt.

cards.name: Vodalian Soldiers
cards.flavor:
"Vodalian Soldiers had some unique advantages. Often they would ride into battle on war machines rumored to have come from the far northern oceans."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. V

cards.name: Vodalian Soldiers
cards.flavor:
"Stalwart Soldiers, you stand against the Homarids for Vodalia and for honor. Your homeland cries out for protection, and the moment has come. Now let your valor shine, and sound the cry to battle. Victory to Vodalia"
—Marshall Volnikov

cards.name: Vodalian Soldiers
cards.flavor:
"You think you know everything there is to know about battle? You know Orc droppings Underwater combat is three dimensional. Those thrice-damned Vodalians don't attack in ranks; they attack in schools."
—Ivra Jursdotter

cards.name: Vodalian Soldiers
cards.flavor:
"The cooling climate introduced a new threat to Vodalia: the Homarids. Once a minor nuisance, they thrived in the changing environment. Their ceaseless attacks strained Vodalia's defenses to their limit, eventually overwhelming the empire."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. V

cards.name: Vodalian War Machine
cards.text:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
Tap an untapped Merfolk you control: Vodalian War Machine can attack this turn as though it didn't have defender.
Tap an untapped Merfolk you control: Vodalian War Machine gets +2/+1 until end of turn.
When Vodalian War Machine dies, destroy all Merfolk tapped this turn to pay for its abilities.

rulings.text: The Merfolk are tapped during announcement and as a cost. The ability can't be announced if the Merfolk are not in an untapped state.

cards.originalText: {0}: Tap target Merfolk you control to allow Vodalian War Machine to attack this turn or to give Vodalian War Machine +2/+1 until end of turn. If Vodalian War Machine is put in the graveyard, all Merfolk tapped in this manner this turn are destroyed.

cards.name: Elven Fortress
cards.text: {1}{G}: Target blocking creature gets +0/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"The size of the obvious Fortress walls often misled foes. Actually, the Elves enchanted the forest itself to provide the first line of defense with tangling vines and stinging thorns."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. III
cards.originalText: {1}{G}: Target blocking creature gets +0/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Elven Fortress
cards.text: {1}{G}: Target blocking creature gets +0/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: Many Elven Fortresses weren't built by masons and carpenters, but created from the living forest itself.
cards.originalText: {1}{G}: Target blocking creature gets +0/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Elven Fortress
cards.text: {1}{G}: Target blocking creature gets +0/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"Thallids are not ordinary enemies of flesh and bone and reason. They attack with no thought for our strength or of their own losses. I fear our Fortresses shall be overwhelmed."
—Kyliki of Havenwood
cards.originalText: {1}{G}: Target blocking creature gets +0/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Elven Fortress
cards.text: {1}{G}: Target blocking creature gets +0/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "Burn it down, you say? Now there's a stupid idea. What do you suppose will become of those overhanging branches, hmmm? And then what do you suppose will become of us?" —Ivra Jursdotter
cards.originalText: {1}{G}: Target blocking creature gets +0/+1 until end of turn.

cards.originalText:
During your upkeep, put a spore counter on Elvish Farmer.
{0}: Remove three spore counters from Elvish Farmer to put a Saproling token into play. Treat this token as a 1/1 green creature.

cards.name: Elvish Hunter
cards.text: {1}{G}, {T}: Target creature doesn't untap during its controller's next untap step.
cards.flavor: The Elves never had a standing army; when battle came, they pressed Hunters, Scouts, and Farmers into a surprisingly effective militia.

rulings.text: You may target any creature with this ability. It doesn't have to be tapped.
If the targeted creature is untapped at the time its controller's next untap step begins, this ability has no effect. It won't apply at some later time when the targeted creature is tapped.

Elvish Hunter doesn't track the creature's controller. If the affected creature changes controllers before its old controller's next untap step, Elvish Hunter will prevent it from being untapped during its new controller's next untap step.

cards.originalText: {1}{G}, {T}: Target creature does not untap as normal during its controller's next untap phase.

cards.name: Elvish Hunter
cards.text: {1}{G}, {T}: Target creature doesn't untap during its controller's next untap step.
cards.flavor:
"Elves often tipped their arrows with a drug that caused a deep but harmless sleep."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. III

rulings.text: You may target any creature with this ability. It doesn't have to be tapped.
If the targeted creature is untapped at the time its controller's next untap step begins, this ability has no effect. It won't apply at some later time when the targeted creature is tapped.

Elvish Hunter doesn't track the creature's controller. If the affected creature changes controllers before its old controller's next untap step, Elvish Hunter will prevent it from being untapped during its new controller's next untap step.

cards.originalText: {1}{G}, {T}: Target creature does not untap as normal during its controller's next untap phase.

cards.name: Elvish Hunter
cards.text: {1}{G}, {T}: Target creature doesn't untap during its controller's next untap step.
cards.flavor:
"As the climate cooled, many Elves turned to Thallid farming for food, while the Hunters honed their skills on what little game remained."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. III

rulings.text: You may target any creature with this ability. It doesn't have to be tapped.
If the targeted creature is untapped at the time its controller's next untap step begins, this ability has no effect. It won't apply at some later time when the targeted creature is tapped.

Elvish Hunter doesn't track the creature's controller. If the affected creature changes controllers before its old controller's next untap step, Elvish Hunter will prevent it from being untapped during its new controller's next untap step.

cards.originalText: {1}{G}, {T}: Target creature does not untap as normal during its controller's next untap phase.

cards.name: Elvish Scout
cards.text: {G}, {T}: Untap target attacking creature you control. Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt to and dealt by it this turn.
cards.flavor:
"Even for Elves, they were stealthy little twerps. They'd taken our measure before we'd even seen them."
—Marshall Volnikov
cards.originalText: {G}, {T}: Untap a target attacking creature you control. That creature neither receives nor deals damage during combat this turn.

cards.name: Elvish Scout
cards.text: {G}, {T}: Untap target attacking creature you control. Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt to and dealt by it this turn.
cards.flavor: Even one whose ears were closely tuned to the sounds of Havenwood could miss hearing a Scout move past.
cards.originalText: {G}, {T}: Untap a target attacking creature you control. That creature neither receives nor deals damage during combat this turn.

cards.name: Elvish Scout
cards.text: {G}, {T}: Untap target attacking creature you control. Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt to and dealt by it this turn.
cards.flavor: Although the Elves of Havenwood lived in isolated villages, their swift communications allowed them to act as a single community.
cards.originalText: {G}, {T}: Untap a target attacking creature you control. That creature neither receives nor deals damage during combat this turn.

cards.name: Feral Thallid
cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, put a spore counter on Feral Thallid.
Remove three spore counters from Feral Thallid: Regenerate Feral Thallid.
cards.flavor:
"Born and bred of fungus, Thallids were nearly impossible to kill."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. I
cards.originalText:
During your upkeep, put a spore counter on Feral Thallid.
{0}: Remove three spore counters from Feral Thallid to regenerate it.

cards.name: Fungal Bloom
cards.text: {G}{G}: Put a spore counter on target Fungus.
cards.flavor:
"Thallids could absorb energy from the forest itself. Even Elves were at a disadvantage in fighting them."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. III
cards.originalText: {G}{G}: Put a spore counter on a target Fungus.

cards.name: Night Soil
cards.text: {1}, Exile two creature cards from a single graveyard: Create a 1/1 green Saproling creature token.
cards.flavor: The Elves gathered huge piles of rot to grow fungus. Out of imitation or forethought, the Thallids did the same.

rulings.text: The two creature cards are exiled as a cost. No one can respond to this. If no graveyard has two creature cards in it, the cost can't be paid.

cards.originalText: {1}: Remove two creatures in any graveyard from the game to put a Saproling token into play. Treat this token as a 1/1 green creature.

cards.name: Night Soil
cards.text: {1}, Exile two creature cards from a single graveyard: Create a 1/1 green Saproling creature token.
cards.flavor: Some said killing the Thallids only encouraged them.

rulings.text: The two creature cards are exiled as a cost. No one can respond to this. If no graveyard has two creature cards in it, the cost can't be paid.

cards.flavor:
"There were often more Thallids after a battle than before."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. III

rulings.text: The two creature cards are exiled as a cost. No one can respond to this. If no graveyard has two creature cards in it, the cost can't be paid.

cards.originalText: {1}: Remove two creatures in any graveyard from the game to put a Saproling token into play. Treat this token as a 1/1 green creature.

cards.name: Spore Cloud
cards.text: Tap all blocking creatures. Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt this turn. Each attacking creature and each blocking creature doesn't untap during its controller's next untap step.

rulings.text: Only makes attackers or blockers that have been declared before the spell is cast unable to untap as normal next turn. So, if used before attackers or blockers are declared, it is simply a Fog-like effect. If used after attackers are declared but before blockers are declared, it does the Fog effect and makes attackers not untap as normal. If done after blockers are declared, it has full effect.

If a creature affected by Spore Cloud is untapped at the time its controller's next untap step begins, the "doesn't untap" effect doesn't do anything. It won't apply at some later time when that creature is tapped.

Spore Cloud doesn't track the creatures' controllers. If an affected creature changes controllers before its old controller's next untap step, Spore Cloud will prevent it from being untapped during its new controller's next untap step.

cards.originalText: Tap all blocking creatures. No creatures deal damage in combat this turn. Neither attacking nor blocking creatures untap as normal during their controllers' next untap phase.

cards.name: Spore Cloud
cards.text: Tap all blocking creatures. Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt this turn. Each attacking creature and each blocking creature doesn't untap during its controller's next untap step.

rulings.text: Only makes attackers or blockers that have been declared before the spell is cast unable to untap as normal next turn. So, if used before attackers or blockers are declared, it is simply a Fog-like effect. If used after attackers are declared but before blockers are declared, it does the Fog effect and makes attackers not untap as normal. If done after blockers are declared, it has full effect.

If a creature affected by Spore Cloud is untapped at the time its controller's next untap step begins, the "doesn't untap" effect doesn't do anything. It won't apply at some later time when that creature is tapped.

Spore Cloud doesn't track the creatures' controllers. If an affected creature changes controllers before its old controller's next untap step, Spore Cloud will prevent it from being untapped during its new controller's next untap step.

cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Thelon's Chant unless you pay {G}.
Whenever a player puts a Swamp onto the battlefield, Thelon's Chant deals 3 damage to that player unless the player puts a -1/-1 counter on a creature they control.

rulings.text: Damages the player putting the land onto the battlefield, even if they are not the controller of the land after it is on the battlefield.
Only checks the type of the land as it is put onto the battlefield. If the land gets changed after it enters the battlefield (even by a continuous effect), the Chant causes no additional effect.

cards.originalText:
During your upkeep, pay {G} or bury Thelon's Chant.
Whenever a player puts a swamp into play, Thelon's Chant deals 3 damage to him or her unless that player puts a -1/-1 counter on a target creature he or she controls.

cards.name: Thelon's Curse
cards.text:
Blue creatures don't untap during their controllers' untap steps.
At the beginning of each player's upkeep, that player may choose any number of tapped blue creatures they control and pay {U} for each creature chosen this way. If the player does, untap those creatures.
cards.originalText: Blue creatures do not untap as normal during their controller's untap phase. During his or her upkeep, a blue creature's controller may pay an additional {U} to untap it. Each creature may be untapped in this way only once per turn.

cards.name: Thelonite Druid
cards.text: {1}{G}, {T}, Sacrifice a creature: Forests you control become 2/3 creatures until end of turn. They're still lands.
cards.flavor:
"The magic at the heart of all living things can bear awe-inspiring fruit."
—Kolevi of Havenwood, Elder Druid

rulings.text: The most recent land animating ability takes precedence.
Can sacrifice the Druid to itself.
Only affects Forests that are on the battlefield when the effect resolves.
The land animation ability does not wear off if the land stops being a Forest. It continues until the end of the turn.

A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of their most recent turn. It doesn't matter how long the permanent has been a creature.

cards.originalText: {1}{G}, {T}: Sacrifice a creature to turn all your forests into 2/3 creatures until end of turn. The forests still count as lands but may not be tapped for mana if they were brought into play this turn.

cards.name: Thelonite Monk
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice a green creature: Target land becomes a Forest. (This effect lasts indefinitely.)
cards.flavor:
"As the climate worsened, some Thelonites turned to fertilizing with fresh blood in an attempt to keep Havenwood alive and growing."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. III

rulings.text: Will not add or remove Snow Supertype to or from a land.

cards.originalText: {T}: Sacrifice a green creature to turn a target land into a basic forest. Mark changed land with a counter.

cards.flavor:

cards.text: Brassclaw Orcs can't block creatures with power 2 or greater.
cards.flavor:

cards.name: Brassclaw Orcs

cards.flavor:

cards.originalText: Cannot be assigned to block any creature of power greater than 1.

cards.name: Dwarven Armorer
cards.text: {R}, {T}, Discard a card: Put a +0/+1 counter or a +1/+0 counter on target creature.
cards.flavor:
"The few remaining pieces from this period suggest the Dwarves eventually made weapons and armor out of everything, even children's toys."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. IV
cards.originalText: {R}, {T}: Discard a card from your hand to put either a +0/+1 or a +1/+0 counter on a target creature.

cards.name: Dwarven Catapult
cards.text: Dwarven Catapult deals X damage divided evenly, rounded down, among all creatures target opponent controls.
cards.flavor:
"Often greatly outnumbered in battle, Dwarves relied on catapults as one means of damaging a large army."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. IV

rulings.text: Count the number of creatures on resolution of the spell and divide X by that number at that time. If the number of creatures changes before resolution, the damage done may be different than what you expected.
For example, if X is 5 and the targeted opponent controls three creatures, Dwarven Catapult deals 1 damage to each of those creatures.
If the targeted opponent controls more than X creatures, no damage will be dealt to any of them.

cards.originalText: Dwarven Catapult does X damage, divided evenly among all of opponent's creatures (round down).

cards.name: Dwarven Lieutenant
cards.text: {1}{R}: Target Dwarf creature gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"Dwarven officers were tireless in battle, moving up and down the lines to rally their troops and boost morale."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. IV
cards.originalText: {1}{R}: Target Dwarf gets +1/+0 until end of turn.

cards.name: Dwarven Soldier
cards.text: Whenever Dwarven Soldier blocks or becomes blocked by one or more Orcs, Dwarven Soldier gets +0/+2 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: There is a legend among present-day Dwarves that the Dwarves of Sarpadia will one day return to defend Dwarvenkind against a deadly peril.
cards.originalText: If Dwarven Soldier blocks or is blocked by Orcs, it gets +0/+2 until end of turn.

cards.name: Dwarven Soldier
cards.text: Whenever Dwarven Soldier blocks or becomes blocked by one or more Orcs, Dwarven Soldier gets +0/+2 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"Let no one say we did not fight until the last . . . ."
—Headstone fragment from a mass grave found in the Crimson Peaks
cards.originalText: If Dwarven Soldier blocks or is blocked by Orcs, it gets +0/+2 until end of turn.

cards.name: Dwarven Soldier
cards.text: Whenever Dwarven Soldier blocks or becomes blocked by one or more Orcs, Dwarven Soldier gets +0/+2 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"Although the Dwarves staunchly defended their walled city-states against the Orcs, their civilization was the first to fall, and its name was sadly lost."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. I
cards.originalText: If Dwarven Soldier blocks or is blocked by Orcs, it gets +0/+2 until end of turn.

cards.name: Goblin Chirurgeon
cards.text: Sacrifice a Goblin: Regenerate target creature.
cards.flavor:
"Perhaps Goblins are good for something after all."
—Attributed to General Khurzog

rulings.text: Can sacrifice itself.
Can also regenerate itself. If it sacrifices itself in an attempt to regenerate itself, the ability won't resolve for having an illegal target.

cards.originalText: {0}: Sacrifice a Goblin to regenerate a target creature.

cards.name: Goblin Chirurgeon
cards.text: Sacrifice a Goblin: Regenerate target creature.
cards.flavor: The Chirurgeons patched up their fallen comrades with a gruesome mix of twisted limbs and mangled flesh.

rulings.text: Can sacrifice itself.

cards.flavor:

—Lydia Wynforth, Mayor of Trokair

rulings.text: Can sacrifice itself.

cards.name: Goblin Flotilla
cards.text:
Islandwalk (This creature can't be blocked as long as defending player controls an Island.)
At the beginning of each combat, unless you pay {R}, whenever Goblin Flotilla blocks or becomes blocked by a creature this combat, that creature gains first strike until end of turn.
cards.flavor: Exceptionally poor sailors, Goblins usually arrived at their destination retching and in no condition to fight.
cards.originalText:
Islandwalk
At the beginning of the attack, pay {R} or any creatures blocking or blocked by Goblin Flotilla gain first strike until end of turn.

cards.name: Goblin Grenade
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, sacrifice a Goblin.
Goblin Grenade deals 5 damage to any target.
cards.flavor:
"According to accepted theory, the Grenade held some kind of flammable mixture and was carried to its target by a hapless Goblin."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. IV

rulings.text: You can't sacrifice more than one Goblin to get a greater effect.
Players can only respond once Goblin Grenade has been cast and all its costs have been paid. No one can try and destroy the Goblin to prevent you from casting Goblin Grenade.
The Goblin you sacrifice to cast Goblin Grenade doesn't have to be a creature. For example, you could sacrifice Boggart Shenanigans (a tribal enchantment with the subtype Goblin).

cards.originalText: Sacrifice a Goblin to have Goblin Grenade deal 5 damage to one target.

cards.name: Goblin Grenade
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, sacrifice a Goblin.
Goblin Grenade deals 5 damage to any target.
cards.flavor:
"I don't suppose we could teach them to throw the cursed things?"
—Ivra Jursdotter

rulings.text: You can't sacrifice more than one Goblin to get a greater effect.
Players can only respond once Goblin Grenade has been cast and all its costs have been paid. No one can try and destroy the Goblin to prevent you from casting Goblin Grenade.

Players can only respond once Goblin Grenade has been cast and all its costs have been paid. No one can try and destroy the Goblin to prevent you from casting Goblin Grenade.

cards.name: Goblin Kites
cards.text: {R}: Target creature you control with toughness 2 or less gains flying until end of turn. Flip a coin at the beginning of the next end step. If you lose the flip, sacrifice that creature.
cards.originalText: {R}: A target creature you control, which cannot have a toughness greater than 2, gains flying until end of turn. Other effects may later be used to increase the creature's toughness. At end of turn, flip a coin; opponent calls heads or tails while coin is in the air. If the flip ends up in opponent's favor, bury that creature.

cards.name: Goblin War Drums
cards.text: Creatures you control have menace. (They can't be blocked except by two or more creatures.)
cards.flavor:
"The Goblins' dreaded War Drums struck terror into the hearts of even their bravest foes."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. IV

rulings.text: When combined with an effect that reads "Each creature you control can't be blocked by more than one creature," none of your creatures can be blocked.
Multiple War Drums are not cumulative. They are redundant.

cards.originalText: Each attacking creature you control that opponent chooses to block may not be blocked with fewer than two creatures.

cards.name: Goblin War Drums
cards.text: Creatures you control have menace. (They can't be blocked except by two or more creatures.)
cards.flavor: The War Drums enabled Goblin and Orcish armies to crush the sparsely defended Dwarven cities.

rulings.text: When combined with an effect that reads "Each creature you control can't be blocked by more than one creature," none of your creatures can be blocked.
Multiple War Drums are not cumulative. They are redundant.

cards.originalText: Each attacking creature you control that opponent chooses to block may not be blocked with fewer than two creatures.

cards.name: Goblin War Drums
cards.text: Creatures you control have menace. (They can't be blocked except by two or more creatures.)
cards.flavor:
"Defending the outer trenches, we strained our eyes in the darkness. All we could hear was the Drums' terrible pounding. Dobbs, on my right, broke first. Soon, we were all heading for the walls."
—Corporal Peter Douglas, courtmartial testimony

rulings.text: When combined with an effect that reads "Each creature you control can't be blocked by more than one creature," none of your creatures can be blocked.
Multiple War Drums are not cumulative. They are redundant.

cards.originalText: Each attacking creature you control that opponent chooses to block may not be blocked with fewer than two creatures.

cards.name: Goblin War Drums
cards.text: Creatures you control have menace. (They can't be blocked except by two or more creatures.)
cards.flavor: When creating a new War Drum, Goblin designers sought out the highest quality skulls. Serra Angel skulls were most highly prized, although most acknowledged that the skull of the exotic Sea Serpent made for a richer tone.

rulings.text: When combined with an effect that reads "Each creature you control can't be blocked by more than one creature," none of your creatures can be blocked.
Multiple War Drums are not cumulative. They are redundant.

cards.originalText: Each attacking creature you control that opponent chooses to block may not be blocked with fewer than two creatures.

cards.name: Goblin Warrens
cards.text: {2}{R}, Sacrifice two Goblins: Create three 1/1 red Goblin creature tokens.
cards.flavor:
"Goblins bred underground, their numbers hidden from the enemy until it was too late."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. IV

rulings.text: The token Goblins can be sacrificed to the Warrens to generate new Goblins.

cards.originalText: {2}{R}: Sacrifice two Goblins to put three Goblin tokens into play. Treat these tokens as 1/1 red creatures.

cards.name: Orcish Captain
cards.text: {1}: Flip a coin. If you win the flip, target Orc creature gets +2/+0 until end of turn. If you lose the flip, it gets -0/-2 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: There's a chance to win every battle.

rulings.text: You choose the target when you activate the ability. You don't flip a coin until the ability resolves.

cards.originalText: {1}: Choose a target Orc. Flip a coin; opponent calls heads or tails while coin is in the air. If the flip ends up in your favor, that Orc gets +2/+0 until end of turn. Otherwise, that Orc gets -0/-2 until end of turn.

cards.name: Orcish Spy
cards.text: {T}: Look at the top three cards of target player's library.
cards.flavor:
"Orcish armies often employed the smaller, swifter, and less intelligent Goblins as spies."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. I
cards.originalText: {T}: Look at the top three cards of target player's library and return them in the same order.

cards.name: Orcish Spy
cards.text: {T}: Look at the top three cards of target player's library.
cards.flavor:
"Yeah, they're ugly, they desert in droves, and their personal habits are enough to make you sick. But I'll say this for Orcs: they make great spies."
—Ivra Jursdotter
cards.originalText: {T}: Look at the top three cards of target player's library and return them in the same order.

cards.name: Orcish Spy

cards.flavor:

cards.name: Orgg
cards.text:
Trample
Orgg can't attack if defending player controls an untapped creature with power 3 or greater.
Orgg can't block creatures with power 3 or greater.
cards.flavor: It's bigger than it thinks.

rulings.text: Whether or not the creatures could attack or block is not important, just whether or not the defending player controls such a creature.

cards.originalText:
Trample
Orgg may not attack if opponent controls an untapped creature of power greater than 2. Orgg cannot be assigned to block any creature of power greater than 2.

cards.name: Raiding Party
cards.text:
Raiding Party can't be the target of white spells or abilities from white sources.
Sacrifice an Orc: Each player may tap any number of untapped white creatures they control. For each creature tapped this way, that player chooses up to two Plains. Then destroy all Plains that weren't chosen this way by any player.

rulings.text: The creatures are tapped during spell resolution.

The color of creature to be tapped is set when the effect is announced and even if you use Sleight of Mind after that, you can't change what color creature needs to be tapped to prevent the destruction.
A player can choose zero or one Plains if they want.

cards.originalText:
Raiding Party may not be the target of white spells or effects.
{0}: Sacrifice an Orc to destroy all plains. A player may tap a white creature to prevent up to two plains from being destroyed. Any number of creatures may be tapped in this manner.

cards.name: Combat Medic
cards.text: {1}{W}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.
cards.flavor:
"Without Combat Medics, Icatia would probably not have withstood the forces of chaos as long as it did."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. VI
cards.originalText: {1}{W}: Prevent 1 damage to any player or creature.

cards.name: Combat Medic
cards.text: {1}{W}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.
cards.flavor:
"Although Icatia's Combat Medics borrowed much of their knowledge from other societies, their skills were their own."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. VI
cards.originalText: {1}{W}: Prevent 1 damage to any player or creature.

cards.name: Combat Medic
cards.text: {1}{W}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.
cards.flavor:
"We'd no sooner knock 'em back on their heels than that accursed sawbones would show up and patch 'em back together again."
—Ivra Jursdotter

cards.name: Combat Medic
cards.text: {1}{W}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.

—Lydia Wynforth, Mayor of Trokair
cards.originalText: {1}{W}: Prevent 1 damage to any player or creature.

cards.name: Farrel's Mantle
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Whenever enchanted creature attacks and isn't blocked, its controller may have it deal damage equal to its power plus 2 to another target creature. If that player does, the attacking creature assigns no combat damage this turn.

rulings.text: If you put this on your opponent's creature, they decide whether or not to make their creature deal no damage to you.

This ability resolves during the declare blockers step. If the damage dealt this way is enough to destroy an attacking or blocking creature, that other creature won't be around to deal its combat damage.

If the same creature is enchanted with more than one Farrel's Mantle, they'll each trigger if that creature attacks and isn't blocked. The creature's controller may have it deal damage multiple times. As long as the enchanted creature's controller chooses to use Farrel's Mantle's ability at least once to deal damage, the enchanted creature will deal no combat damage.

If the enchanted creature's controller chooses to have it deal no combat damage, that combat damage is not prevented. It's simply not dealt. A creature whose damage can't be prevented (such as Excruciator) would deal no combat damage this way.

The enchanted creature's controller cannot choose to have the enchanted creature deal damage to itself. If there are no other creatures on the battlefield, then a legal target cannot be chosen so the ability does nothing.

An ability that triggers when something "attacks and isn't blocked" triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText: If target creature attacks and is not blocked, it may deal X+2 damage to any other target creature, where X is the power of the creature Farrel's Mantle enchants. If it does so, it deals no damage to opponent this turn.

cards.name: Farrel's Zealot
cards.text: Whenever Farrel's Zealot attacks and isn't blocked, you may have it deal 3 damage to target creature. If you do, Farrel's Zealot assigns no combat damage this turn.
cards.flavor: Farrel, a former priest, believed Icatia was far too complacent toward the Order of the Ebon Hand.

rulings.text: In a multiplayer game, the target creature does not need to be one of the ones controlled by the player you actually attacked.

This ability resolves during the declare blockers step. If the damage dealt this way is enough to destroy an attacking or blocking creature, that other creature won't be around to deal its combat damage.
If there are no other creatures on the battlefield, Farrel's Zealot will have to target itself. Of course, you can choose not to use the ability when it resolves.

An ability that triggers when something "attacks and isn't blocked" triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText: If Farrel's Zealot attacks and is not blocked, you may choose to have it deal 3 damage to a target creature. If you do so, it deals no damage to opponent this turn.

cards.name: Farrel's Zealot
cards.text: Whenever Farrel's Zealot attacks and isn't blocked, you may have it deal 3 damage to target creature. If you do, Farrel's Zealot assigns no combat damage this turn.
cards.flavor: Farrel and his followers became a formidable band of vigilantes, battling Icatians and followers of Tourach.

rulings.text: In a multiplayer game, the target creature does not need to be one of the ones controlled by the player you actually attacked.

This ability resolves during the declare blockers step. If the damage dealt this way is enough to destroy an attacking or blocking creature, that other creature won't be around to deal its combat damage.
If there are no other creatures on the battlefield, Farrel's Zealot will have to target itself. Of course, you can choose not to use the ability when it resolves.

It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.text: Whenever Farrel's Zealot attacks and isn't blocked, you may have it deal 3 damage to target creature. If you do, Farrel's Zealot assigns no combat damage this turn.
cards.flavor: After the fall of Trokair, Farrel and his followers formally broke their ties with the rest of Icatia.

rulings.text: In a multiplayer game, the target creature does not need to be one of the ones controlled by the player you actually attacked.

This ability resolves during the declare blockers step. If the damage dealt this way is enough to destroy an attacking or blocking creature, that other creature won't be around to deal its combat damage.
If there are no other creatures on the battlefield, Farrel's Zealot will have to target itself. Of course, you can choose not to use the ability when it resolves.

An ability that triggers when something "attacks and isn't blocked" triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText: If Farrel's Zealot attacks and is not blocked, you may choose to have it deal 3 damage to a target creature. If you do so, it deals no damage to opponent this turn.

cards.name: Farrelite Priest
cards.text: {1}: Add {W}. If this ability has been activated four or more times this turn, sacrifice Farrelite Priest at the beginning of the next end step.
cards.flavor: Although their methods were often brutal, Farrel's followers believed in the preservation of justice and virtue.
cards.originalText: {1}: Add {W} to your mana pool. Play this ability as an interrupt. If more than 3 is spent in this way during one turn, bury Farrelite Priest at end of turn.

cards.name: Hand of Justice
cards.text: {T}, Tap three untapped white creatures you control: Destroy target creature.
cards.flavor:
"The Hand of Justice will come to cleanse the world if we are true."
—Oliver Farrel

rulings.text: It can destroy one of the three creatures it taps.

cards.originalText: {T}: Tap three target white creatures you control to destroy any target creature.
